cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Fast steamers leave Alexandris every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 pm., for JAFFA (tor Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazaretb), BEIRUT (for Damascus. TRIPÓLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MERSINE, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus.)

Red Sea Line. Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct retur, in from Suskin every Wednesday doon. Every Monday at 6 pm, a steamer leaves Sues for Jedda continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jadilah bot call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.

div.p: Tolima Fluor Cream est la seule crème qui ne contient ni de la graisse ni de l'huile. Discrètement parfumée cette crème nettoie la peau admirablement, donne une blancheur de perle, et communique la vitalité aux tissus, l'élasticité aux muscles, et une fraîcheur délicieuse par toute la peau. Ses vertus uniques dérivent d'une eau minérale naturelle, ainsi on peut bien l'appeler

p.hi: Crème naturelle et la peau n'a besoin que de cette crème pour s'as. surer la vitalité nécessaire pour résister aux rayons du soleil, à la chaleur au froid et aux effets désastreux des eaux saumâtres, pour empêcher et guérir les irritations et les vices du sang surchauffé, et pour conserver la jeunesse fraîche et sans les rides, qui arrivent si vite dans les pays chauds.
L'emploi de cette crème éloigne beaucoup les insectes et les moustiques et soulage immédiatement de leurs piqûres. Dépôt pour l'Egypte : J. Macgregor, Pharmaplan

div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER.
ESTABLISHED 1880. Editor and Kanagar . . R. SKELLIG.
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
FRIDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1966

THE SULTAN'S SUCCESSOR The Constantinople correspondent of the "Tribune” in a recent letter to our contemporary concerning the much discussed question of the succession to the throne of Turkey writes as follows:- For some weeks there have mysterious rumours of the possibility of an attempt to change the succession to the Turkish throne. The most persistent is that it is the desire of Abdul Hamid to appoint his third son, Prince Burhan-ed-din, as his successor,and for this purpose to obtain the consent of the Sheik-ul Islam and of the Ambassadors of the Great Powers. It is even added that Abdul Hamid is thinking of abdicating in favour of this prince. The rumoured step would be an exceedingly grave one. It is probable that any attempt to make such a change without the consent of the ulema class, of whom the Sheikul-Islam is the head, would fail, and might simply plunge the country into revolution. It is further rumoured that the Sheik-ul-Islam has een sounded, and that he has declared that such a change could never be sanctioned. This, however, I do not believe. Rumour further says that the German Emperor has been asked for his counsel, and that the sudden return here, & week lago, of the German Ambassador is in connexion with this question. While fully admitting that we are dealing only with rumours, these are so persistent and definite as to suggest that they have a basis of truth, and the questions raised by them become interesting and important.

The Moslem law of succession to a royal throne is based upon long usage, and enacts that the heir is the eldest male in the Royal or Imperial family. A simple illustration is furnished by the recent history of Egypt, When Mehmet Ali became, by Imperial firman and the recognition of Europe, Khedive of Egypt, the Sultan issued a firman in 1846 by which the succession was to be regulated in the Moslem fashion--that is, the heir was always to be the eldest male descended from Mehmet Ali. The rule was strictly followed till the time of Ismail. On the death of Ismail the legal heir to the Khedival throne should have been Prince Halim, the youngest son of Mehmet Ali. But Ismail, in 1866, by means of very heavy payments, had induced Abdul Aziz, the Sultan of Turkey (who was deposed, and "suicided" in 1876), to grant a new firman, by which the succession was changed from the Moslem to the general European system of succession. When the representatives of England and France decided in 1879 to get rid of Ismail, they secretly, but unmistakably, gave him the opportunity to leave Egypt quietly, in which case the firman which he had obtained would be re-1. cognized, and his son allowed to reign in his stead. If he refused, Halim, the "de jure'' heir by Moslem law, would be placed on the throne. He agreed to go quietly. It was generally believed in this city that Abdul Aziz, in granting the firman changing the Egyptian succession, had the intention to change the succession to the Turkish throne. In such case Prince Yussuf Izzedin would have been the heir apparent, The revolution of 1876 put an end to any such design, and Murad, and then the present occupant, were girded with the Sword of Osman in conformity with the well-established rule. At the time, however, when the project of changing the Ottoman rule of succession was in the air, it was well

understood that the ulema class were strongly opposed to it. They represent the conservative element of Islam; and unless some very special circumstances should be brought forward, they would oppose a stout resistance to any change of the kind. The present heir to the throne is Reshad Effendi, the Sultan's brother. Both he and two elder brothers rank, on the ground of age, before the third son of the present Sultan. The supposed favourite of his Majesty for the secession is his third son, who is known to the Ambassadors as a bright and intelligent young man of about twenty years old. The question is mainly, though not exclusively, of course, one for the subjects of his Majesty, and especially for his Moslem subjects. If the change is attempted, it will probably give rise to considerable trouble.

The suggestion that Abdul Hamid would be willing to abdicate does not strike me as probable. Those who are in favour of his doing so speak disparagingly of Reshad Effendi; but there will always be a party strongly in his favour as representing the reign of Moslem law. There are precedents for passing over the heir, but the change has always been regarded as revolutionary.

Though, of course, the personality of the Sultan is for foreign States a matter of great importance, the representatives of such States will probably best consult the interests of their Governments, and certainly of Turkey, by having nothing to do with any proposal to change the succession. The fact that they or any of them favoured one candidate more than another would do much to make him unpopular with the Moslem population. The matter is primarily one for the Moslem people of Turkey, and for a foreign Government to pronounce an opinion one way or another would have the appearance of mixing in a Palace intrigue. If it be said that Turkey is more or less under European tutelage, and that the unanimous consent of Europe to a change of Moslem law would give it a sanction which would secure its general acceptance, my reply would be that unanimity on this subject is impossible, and to attempt to obtain it would occasion endless intrigue. It may be admitted that if the general consent of Europe could be obtained it might establish an important precedent. But if such consent has been applied for, and if, as is rumoured, negotiations are going on, it is because opposition is anticipated either by Turkey or by some foreign State. Even an attempt by the Concert of Europe would be denounced by the Moslem population as an interference by the giaours with their religious rights.

There is much to be said for and much against the alleged project. The generally expressed opinion is that certain Palace favourites, for their own purposes, are in its favour, and this would not recommend it to the Turkish population, and still less to Europeans. Indeed, in whatever way the expe. diency of a change in the law of succession may be regarded, its practical application will be dangerous. It will almost certainly lead to disturbances, and it ought to be a question for Turkish statesmen whether it is desirable to add to the many difficulties with which they have to deal a possible war of succession. For foreign states the question is at once tempting and dangerous. In the solution of the many questions in the Near East with which our country is concerned, it is difficult to see what advantage could be gained by entering upon it. Sir Edward Grey will probably conclude that his wisest course is to reserve speech or action, and take up the position that Great Britain will stand sloot, and neither approve or disapprove any action of the kind which the Palace advisers may choose. to take.
BOVRIL
A -lb. bottle of Bovril yields 10 to 1 cups of a highly nutritious and stim. ulating beverage

- "Al Minbar” states in its issue of yesterday that it has received an official communication announcing that the journal will not be admitted into the Soden. We can only express approval at the action of the Sudan Government in view of the immoderation with which "Al Minbar" discusses political question relating to the occupying Power. The organs of the nationalist party have assumed the foolish course of indulging in mere tirade against the advisers of the Khedive, and by such bring upon themselves the possibility of a perfectly justifiable suppression. We are rather inclined to hope that the prohibition of such intemperate journals in the Body is an allegory of the application of a censorship over the Press of Egypt. It is exceedingly regrettable that there should be cause to seriously consider such an innovation, but a certain section, which is not constituted by our vernacular contemporaries alone, has become so seditions that we should feel ourselves obliged to support the Government in any means which they might deem necessary to check the violent and harmful declamations of reasoning journalists. Let auch take a lesson from the suppression of "Al Minbar" in the Sudan, and learn that their turbulence may preclude them from the liberty which moderation would ensure and from the consideration of serious men.
LOCAL AND GENERAL.
The Plague
Two new plagne patients were admitted to hospital at Saez yesterday and one patient was discharged Assiut Ophthalmic Hospital.
The new Ophthalmic Hospital at Assioat was formally opened yesterday in the presence of the mondir of the province. Melouan Observatory. .
The observatory will be open to the public on the 11th inst. on which occasion the survey Department will be "at home." Military Exemption.
The military exemption tax between January 1 and August 31, 1906, realized L.E.164,900 as against LE. 116,990 for the same period last year. St. Andrew's Church, Alexandria
The sacrament of the Lord's Supper will be celebrated on Sunday morning at the close of the morning service. Friends and visitors are cordially invited. The Pilgrimage
Two days ago, 150 Turkish pilgrims arrived at Cairo, where they passed & couple of days and they have now proceeded to Saez to embark for the Hedjaz. Law School Graduates.
By sanction of the Ministry of Justice, number of graduates of the Khedivial Law School have been appointed "substituts da parquet" at the native coorte. European Polloe for Egypt.
Provision has been made in the budget of the Ministry of the Interior for 1907 for the European police who are to be attached to the forcəs at Cairo and Alexandria. Cairo Circulating Library.

On and after Monday, 8th October, the Cairo Circulating Library will be open at the usual winter honrs, viz, from 10.90 a.m. to midday and from 4.30 to 6 p.m. of each day except Sunday. Comptoir National d'Escompte.

The Cairo branch of the Comptoir National dE-compte, Paris, to be inaugurated on the 15th ist., will be temporarily housed in the Maison Manusardi, Emad el Dia Aveeno, near the Hotel d'Angleterre. National University.

The absorption towards the foundation of a National 'University has reached L. B. 2,100. It is feared in some quarters that this scheme of a National University will share the same fate as that drawn ap by several Khedivial princes and Egyptian notables at the time of the Mohamed Ali centenary. Suez Canal

On October 3, 6 vessels, 2 northward and 4 southward boond, transited the Canal and paid Fr. 177,712 59 for transit and passenger toll. Of these vessels, 3 were British, 2 German and i Austrian. The total receipts since October 1 are Fr. 639,119.92, paid by 25 vessels, of which 9 were northward and 16 southward bou: d. Slave Trade.

Mohamed Naeger, the notorious slave dealer, has at last been caught, after having eluded the vigilance of the authorities for eight years. Mbame t, who is the head of the El Parayat tribe, is famous for the pitched battle be fought with the police on September 28, 1905, where ten of his band were arrested and condemned to 15 years' hard labour. Lately the band were surprised with 12 leaves, whom the patrol, however, were unable to liberate, owing to the resistance shown by the Bedouing. New Employment Registry.

The British (bamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance.. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. (Advt.)

Rome, October 4. Signor Nerazzini, Italian Consul General at Shanghai, has been appointed Minister at Tangier, and Cav. Malmosi transferred to Cairo. Marquis Salvago Raggi bas been transferred to Zapzitar. Signor L. Mercatelli has been appointed Consul-General at Calcutta. Signor Medana, Consol-General at Tripoli, has been transferred to Tehran. Signor A. Monaco, Consul-General at Seoul, has been transferred to Shanghai.
Rome, October 4. M. Malmasi, Minister at Morocco. bas been appointed Minister at Cairo, vice the Marquis Salvago-Raggi, who is appointed Consul-General at Zanzibar and Governor of Benadir. (H.)

The snocessor to the Marquis Salvago-Raggi at Cairo, Signor Giulio Malmusi, was born at Parms on the 15th April, 1841, and entered the Foreign Office at Rome on the 14th January, 1861. In the following year he was appointed a Vice-Cowgul of the third class ap 1 proceeded to Barcelona. He was advanced to the second olass in 1865. He has been ViceCoprol at Gibraltar, Bons, and Trebizond. In 1872 he became a Vice-Consul of the first class and a Chevalier of the Crown of Italy two years afterwards. He went to Cairo as Consul in 1874 and to Alexandria in 1877, hence he was transferred to Phillipopolis in 1879. He became Agent and Consul General at Tonis in 1884 and subsequently held the Consul. General Ship at Liverpool and Trieste and was appointed Minister Plenipotentiary at Tangiers in 1695. In 1999 he was nominated Consul. General of the First Class.
THE KHEDIVE.
This morning, the Khedive came from Montazah to Ras El Tin Palace, and at noon proceeded to the Chamrawi mosque in the Customs quarter, where his Highness attended prayer.
SIR VINCENT CORBETT.

Quidnuncs in Cairo are busy finding a post in the diplomatic service for Sir Vincent Corbett, owing to the rumours afloat as to the Financial Advisor leaving the service of the Egyptian Government in order to take up a position coder the Foreign Office. Last week they had discovered a high position for him in the Legation at Brussels ; the week before it was Vienna!
THE LABBAN AFFAIR.
POLICEMEN NOT GUILTY.

The Gouvernorat has received an official communication from the Parquet notifying that Onbashi Mohamed Tahs and shawish Ibrahim Abd-el-Aal, who were charged with having caused the death of Osman Ahmed have been acquitted as not guilty and ordered to resume their duties..
The following is a summary of the contents of the document sent by the Parqnet Général Cairo, to the Chef de Parquet of Alexandria in regard to the fair :

Having carefully examined the official papers of inquiry held by the Alexandrian Parque, and the decision of the Council of Discipline held at the Alexandria Gouvernorat, regarding the death of Osman Ahmed, we find that the policemen Mohamed Tabs and Ibrahim Abdel. Aal are quite blamelers on the ground that medical reports show that the death of the deceased was due to internal disease. The trial of the accused held by the Council of Discipline contains no evidence to incriminate the onbashi and shawish, and, moreover, the two witnesses being of the deceased's relatives, who preferred the charge against the policemen, their evidence can not be considered and furthermore the gap position that the policemen treated the man with some cruelty in the course of their duties affords, insufficient ground to incriminate them.
THE CENSUS OF EGYPT.

The preparations for taking the census of Egypt have already begun. Mr. Lewis, whose services have been engaged for taking the census by the Egyptian Government on account of his great experience in similar work in India, arrived at Alexandria yesterday, and paid a visit to the Alexandria Municipality in order to obtain some preliminary information on the subject of his new duties.
WINDSOR HOTEL.

The following visitors are staying at the Windsor Hotel, Alexandris :- Lady Watts, Miss Bill, Mr. Bill, J. Whitworth, Mr. J Addie, Mr. Jullien, Mr. J. Kerr Mr. and Ms. Sergeant, Mr. W. Nboa nor, Mr. Witwortb, Mr. L. Asher, Mr. Greiz, Mr. Danbar, Mr. Bustan, Mr. Skofog, Mr. Barietty, Mr. Britain, Mr. Boulad, Capt. Halse, Mr. Harris, Mr. Davidson. Mr. Calender.

Owen Bey and Pokey Pashs are on their way to Akaba from Rafab, superintending en route the erection of boundary pillars on each side of the frontier, at intervals of one mile. We understand that on their arrival at Akaba they will return by way of fort Nakbl on the way to Suez, from whence they will proceed direct to Cairo. We are assured that the relations between the Anglo Egyptian and Ottoman Commissioners were extremely friendly.

On the other hand, Mr. Keeling. of the Survey Department, who was attached to the Commission, bad & narrow esos pe between Akabs and Koseims, at the bands of a raiding party of Bedouins, who had etussed the frontier to attack one of the Bedonin tribes under Egyptian protection. As Mr. Keeling's guide belonged to the latter tribe bis position might have proved very dangerous, but the Bedouins. fortunately did not press their enquiries too close by Mr. Keeling's guide succeeded in persuading the leaders of the raiding party that he had no connexion whatever with their enemies.
THE PROPOSED BANQUET.
Oar Nationalist confrères are making the best of their time before Moustapha Pa-ba Kamel returns. "Al Moayad '' criticises the Pasha', letter to Parid Bey as insincere.
Oar con frère remarks :

"He still considers his enemies and his critics as opponents of trae patriotism, enemies of all honest devotion to their country. He is modest --ho only hopes that the great gift of a University will be offered to Egypt in bis mime! We suppose be intends to lay the foundation stone himself.”

"Al Watan", the well-known Coptic organ, remarks À prope of the Pasha's letter to Farid Bey :- "Mustapha Pasba Kamel is far too modest in his assertion that he has done nothing worth repeating. He forgets or pretends to forget that be has sowa the seeds of disoord between Moslem and Copt, between Egyptian and Syrian ; that he bas declared Bngland to bethe deadly foe of Islam; that he has taught Moelem to bate Christian, has brought England's anger apon 08, has created that state of exoitement among as which was described as fanaticism in the English Parliament and that he is the cause of all measures taken or to be taken by Bogland to close ber grip on the land and responsible for the very apflattering opinion the English have formed of 98."
"Al Mokattam” learns from a correspondent the details of the mena at the banquet which will be given to Moustapha Pasha at the Grand Continental hotel.
Meat Soup
Turkey Cakes
Bamia
Pastry with cream Vine leaves stuffed with minced meat
Baklawa Grilled meat Turkish Delight
Salade Omel filfil (Bean soup with pepper)

Rice. The writer adds : I hope that all who have found in patriotism & source of profit and an occasion for good cheer will not lose this saperb occasion of regaling themselves at their ease on dishes which are truly national.
The "Journal dn Caire" remarks :

D'une mentalité assez valgaire, d'une intelligenoe tout-à-fait ordinaire, d'une sensibilité médiocre, il tomba dans le "ridicale". Ce n'est pas à vingt-cinq ans, quand on ignore encore la vie et qu'on n'a rien d'on apôtre, qu'on peut prétendre goider la "conscienos" d'ane nation. A demi éclairé (car il n'a qa'une demi-instraction, et il est vraiment un "primaire”) il se orut assez puissant pour entrainer le pays à sa suite et assez babile poor éviter tous les obstacles. Il n'était en réalité qoe naïf. Je veux penser que jarques-là il fut sincère. Mais à partir de ce moment, à moins d'être absolument stapide, il dat s'aperoevoir que la lutte était vaine et que l'Egypte jamais, ne pourrait se nationaliser. Alors nous avons découvert ce que valaient, en réalité, ses grandes revendications, son grand patriotisme et son grand désintéressement

Son devoir ent été de sacrifier ses idées chimériques et à défaut de la "nationalisation" impossible, il devait accepter la domination anglaise qui a procuré du moins à son paye la véritable liberté, la sécarité, et qui a mis fin à la tyrannie et à l'esclavage. Il ent da s'effreer-cela s'est fait en Algérie, opendant-d'amortir les heurts des deux ames étrangères, de créer une sympathie effective, un lien entre les deux nations. Mais quoi ! Son rôle eût été trop humble et il rêvait de destinés plas brillante. Alors, avec son valgaire tempérament d'opposition, il s'est tourné vers la Tarqnie, Désorm is il devenait masalman avant d'être égyptien. La vanité l'avenglait, il perdait peu à psa, ce sons des réalités sana lequel on n'est qu'un "brouillon", on politicien imbésile, on bavard...
Il revendiquait la liberté de son pays et à la domination sage, libre et prévoyante d'une nation européenne, il préférait la domination fanatique, tatillonne et hypoorite de la Tur. qnie

Il se disait patriote et il préparait la mort de l'Egypte. Car la vie d'un peuple n'est florissante q 1e sons on gonvernement éclairé et évolationniste. Oe la Turquie rétrograde et pourrie s'étonffo dans un passé politique sans franchise et sans liberté.
A correspondent writes as follows :

You published the day before yesterday a letter to the "Times" from the pen of Mr. Blunt, who therein expresses his "unlooked for pleasure" at finding himself "one more attacked, after a silence of some twenty years" by bis old adversary, Mr, Moberly Bell One can fully understand Mr. Blant's delight at the advertisement which he has received from a journal than which none other in the world stands bigber, and were it not impossible to disregard the aspersions by which he tries to vilify his mother-dation, the publicity which he has received would be regrettable. Righteous indignation pickles in the heart of every true Britisher at the calamities which are oast upon bis nation by distorted facts emanating from one of the Empire's sons. Were Mr. Blunt content to criticise his country in an equitable spirit, to endeavour to obtain true and unbiased accounts of the happenings in Egypt, and to moderate bis acrimony, one might read with interest and seriously consider his Writing. But his obvious hatred for his country makes one feel that it is impossible to wage with bim the war of pens with the feeling that be is an adversary worthy of the steel.

Mr. Blant's asseveration that the "Times" exaggerates his anti-English attitude cannot be accepted, as, in the opinion of every right minded person, a man who is guilty of such misrepresentation of facts and hyperbolical statements to the detriment of his country, as are contained in his writings, can only be pronounced an an'i nationalist. We are well aware that his interest in the affairs and people of Egypt is of the keenest, and on such a point we could heartily agree with him, but in making it his obvious aim to sully the name of Great Britaia in bor dealing, with a country which she has spatched from the abyss of bankraptey and slavery and raised almost to the pinnacle of prosperity be estranges that sympatby, which serious men could otherwise hold for him. There might be some slight exons were Mr. Blant ignorant of this country and its people, but he has passed a considerable portion of twenty-five years in Egypt, during which time be bad seriously studied the customs of the modern Egyptians, and he cannot have failed to note the unwavering march of progre38 that the country has made under our guidance. Indeed, one is driven to doubt the sincerity of the land of Little-Englanders wbore cry of "British injustice in Egypt" is now so pro prominent, especially in view of the fact that one of the most conspicuous of these has a fall knowledge of the country from personal experience.

That Mr. Blant's latest publication will | receive credenos in Bagland is hardly likely, for, happily, the majority of the home Pross has dealt with the regrettable incident of Danish wai in that equitable spirit which is still the predominant characteristic of the Britisher, despite the attempts of a small declamatory party to persuade the world of the contrary. There is the danger, however, that it may, in conjunction with the impetuous orations of certain members of Parliament and vehement articles of a few journalists lead some to doubt the wisdom with which the representatives of Great Britain are directing the Government of Bzyp", and, though these will speedily be convinced of the injaatioe of such a conolasion if they care to study the question more deeply, a certain amount of mischief may be caused. It is somewhat remarkable that Mr. Blant should play a prominent part in the endeavour of a few self styled nationalists to foment the native to the verge of fanaticism, when he asserts such interest in their welfare, as he must surely realise that any forcible demonstration would be to the serious disadvantage of the people. The irrationality of Mr. Blant and his fellow antinationalists, in addition to filling us with contempt, draw upon us the contomely of foreign nations, who come to the not anpataral conclusion that the abundance of Anglophobe Britishers/ is an indication of the deterioration of our race. As the crow pounces with avidity upon carrion, so sach men seize every opportunity to belittle their fellow countrymen in the eyes of other nations. England, alas, is being nauseat. ed by an unparalleled wave of anti-British hysteris, which became epidemio at the commencement of the Boer war, and the sound of raucous voices pouring undeserved reproach upon men who are conscientiously and successfally striving to farther the interests of coon tries which the first Power of the world has taken under her wing has become sufficiently common to constitate a peril to the Empire. It is deplorable that men of our own nationality endeavour to hide their utter lack of patriotism under a sparious cloak of humanitarianism, and hold ap to the world as martyrs semi-barbarians who have been guilty of an extraordinarily bratal outrage. Such absolute anti-nationalism is incomprehensible, and the attempt of our Little-Baglanders to drive their mother country on to the rooks is worse than dastardly.

The 8.8. Tebe, of the Nxvigazione Generale Italians, sailed from Messins at 2 p.m., yogtarday, wi:b 100 first and second class pas. sengers, and is due here on Sunday.
INSTRUMENTAL CONCERTS

div.p: Every Night On the Verandah of the WINDSOR, HOTEL

p.hi: ALEXANDRIA. FROM 6 TO 12 P.M. 6 O'clock Tea Served on Verandah,
THE MONEY FAMINE.

The prevailing scarcity of geld has to-day been very considerably alleviated by the prompt action of the Government in conjunction with the National Bank. Certain bonds which are not available in ordinary cases have been placed as a temporary measure by the Government at the National Bank's disposal. l'be mere knowledge of this fact, combined with the assistance given by the Bank to the market, bas obanged the aspect of affairs, and financial circles have resumed their normal activity at this season of the year.

The thanks of the financial and mercantile community are due to the Egyptian Government for the ready way it took measures to reset a situation which was causing serious inconvenience not only in Alexandria, but also in Cairo and the interior.

It appears to be popularly believed that if a State Bank was in existence in Egypt, it would be able to prevent any similar crisis owing to its large reserve. But if such a bank were established, it would in all probability find it advantageous to keep its reserve in London just as the other bank, do, seeing that money can be obtained by telegram in six days. To keep a large reserve permanently in Egypt would involve loss of interest daring the summer to a considerable extent.

As we remarked yesterday, it has been suggested that the Government and the Caisse de la Dette are somewhat to be blamed for the existing string sy, as so much money gets looked upon its receipt in payment of taxes Bat it would be as well to remind your readers that, in virtue of the Anglo-French Agreement of 1904, the receipts of the land tax are paid in to the Caisse de la Dette, which has no power to release these sums, while the balance of the Government revenues are sufficient at this season of the year to meet the outgoings in the shape of ordinary expenditure. Consequently no blame for such a striogenoy can fall on the Government. It is, on the contrary, the banks upon whom the responsibility falls in failing to be prepared for such an extraordinary contingency by making proper provision. On the other hand we do not consider that the banker can be held to be so fall of foresight as to anticipate such unexampled prices at the opening of the cotton season. It will be remembered that temporary orises of this natare are by no means unprecedented is the commercial records of Alexandria, and all soch orises have been invariably alleviated in a few days time by the arrival of money from London.

As the currency of Egypt is practicably in British sovereigns, it is very easy to remedy any stringency by merely wiring to London. If, however, the currency were purely Bryptian, it is quite possible that a most serious situation would arise under similar circumstances.
PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
Lady Valda Maobell, the wife of the Adviser of the Ministry of the Interior, was delivered of a daughter, still born, at St. James's Palace on the 25th olto.

Mr. and Lady Velda Machell have been staying at St. James's Palace in the rooms which have been lent to them by Princess Victor Hohenlohe, who is herself at Frensham for the time being. We understand that Mr. Machell leaves London to-day to j in the P. &0. mail steamer Osiris at Brindisi, and is done here on Wednesday.
H.E. Arz Pasha Izzat, under-secretary to the Ministry for Foreign affairs, arrived in Cairo on Wednesday evening on his return from Europe.
Mahmoud Pasha Sidki, Governor of Cairo, came down to Alexandria yesterday evening.

Dean Batcher has been staying at Wesson on Lake Walensee. We regret to hear that he has been confined to his bed for some days. A sudden abnormal drop in the temperature brought on a rather severe bronchial attack, but we are glad to learn that the attack is yielding to treatment, and we hope that be will soon recover his strength.

Professor Gottschlich, sanitary inspector of Alexandria, has returned to Egypt from Europe and resumed his official duties. He has been attending the medical congress at Lisbon on behalf of the Alexandria Municipality.
Mr. James Wilson, of Newcastle University, has been appointed professor at the school of | arts and crafts at Boulao.

THE ISIS DISASTER.

We are informed by the brad office of the Postal Administration that the Brindisi mail will arrive at Port Said at six o'clock to-morrow evening and that the Alexandris distribution will commence at 8 a.m. on Sunday.

It will be observed from the Roater's telegram which we append that the Lois has been sufficiently repaired to be able to continue its voyage. Doubt Lose she will be accompanied by the Persis, which, as we reported yesterday, went to her help on receipt of the news at Port Said, so that in the event of further break down every assistance will be at hand.
Among the passengers who, according to Reuter's despatch of the day before yesterday, Tan so gross risk of serious injury, were Mr.
. Aspinall, the popular secretary to the Turf Club, Cairo, and Mr. Goorge Walker, of the firm of Messrs. Walker and Moi mariachi.
The weekly Brindisi mail will be made up at the G. P. 0., 'Alexandrio, on Sanday at 3.10 p.m. for ordinary correspondence. Registered letters must be posted on board earlier.
ZANTE, October 4. The Isis has left with passengers and mails for Port Ssid, where she is expected to arrive on Saturday,
We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions or
pressed by our correspondente, bat we wish, in spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain nocosmary Hasit free discussion.
OFFICIALS AND CIVILIANS.
To the EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.".

Sir,-It is a thousand pities that "A Mere Business Man" should have so wis-read to letter I wrote to you from the Payoum • few days ago. I was the labouring under the impression that I was accusing one of your correspondents of snobbishness in speaking slightingly of the benefits of Board School Education. I ventured to point out the superiority of a Board School Education to that of Public School and "Varsity, and I spok, of the latter form of education as being possibly « misfortune / Will "A More Business Man" do mo the favour of roading my letter once again and more carefully, and then informing me whance ba ipfors that I consider that the British Commercial Community here has enjoyed Board Sobool odao tion ? No such insinuation was made, and moreover the benefits of Board School Education were described in superior to those of 'Varsity and Publio Sobool odoontion. How the remarks in my letter could have been so distorted as to bring about a meaning contrary to that intended is hard to imagino 1

There seems to be considerable bittersom shown on the part of the unofficial PORTER pondents in this controversy. Let thom root assured that this bitterness is in no way reciprocated, and that the greatest admiration and respect for our commercial follow countrymen bere, who do so mooh te koop England's name and reputation bright, no telp by all Anglo-Bgyptian officials, not excluding
"CIVILIAN OFFICIAL." Rosetta, October 4.
To the Editor OF THE "BGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, -The charge made against "five or six civilian officials" by your correspondent "Box Offi-sio" appears to me to be an argument in favour of my original suggestion, that all Government officials or employés should wear the tarbusb as a protection against being taken for members of the commercial community. Sarely if the official class adopted the suggestion made in my letter of the 19th September and, wore some distinguishing badge Do such charge as that referred to above could. be made against a community composed of gentlemen who are mostly University schoları, and who as such, I feel sore, would never disgrace themselves in the manner stated to have occurred in the small hours of the morning.--I am, eto.
ANOTHER RESIDENT OF
OVER 80 YEARS STANDING. Cairo, October 4.
TO THE EDITOR OF TAS "EGYPTIAN GAZETTA."

Sir. – The ideal condition of existence in Cairo would be a community of Anglo-Bgyptians officials, andistarbed by the presence of any commercial people of their own race. The British commercial man is doubt lou « vory well-meaning person in his way, but bii prosonce introduces a certain jarring noto and I fally sympathise with the attitude of French and German officialdom, who in the so-called colonies of those nations do their boot to ensure a tranquil life by suppressing the com mercial men of their own race by making their existence intolerable. However, for good or ill, such is not the policy of the British Government and in Cairo we should learn to tolerate them. We need not arouse their irritation by patronising airs and should always rather adopt a condescending attitude to this class of human beings, but at the same time if they consider that their racial relationship to as affords them a special right to oritioing, they should be taught to keep to their place. The best way of treating these people is to adopt an attitude of studied irony towards theta. Sach treatment would prevent them from becoming familiar, as it appears to pozzle them.--I am, truly yours.
CANTAB. Cairo, October 4,
